Sam Stites

2016-08-16-multi-parameter-type-classes

Multi-parameter Type Classes

If a single-parameter type class implies a set of types, then a multi-parameter type class is a relationship between types.

If we want to have some kind of generic collection type, we would create a typeclass like so:

class Collection c where
  insert :: c -> e -> c
  member :: c -> e -> Bool

instance Collection [a] where
  insert xs x = x:xs
  member = flip elem

However the Collection typeclass has no idea what e is. To correct this we use a multi-parameter type clas:

{-# LANGUAGE MultiParamTypeClasses #-}
class Eq e => Collection c e where
  insert :: c -> e -> c
  member :: c -> e -> Bool

{-# LANGUAGE FlexibleInstances #-} -- out of order, purely for example
instance Eq a => Collection [a] a where
  insert = flip (:)
  member = flip elem

We can, furthermore, add constraints to these relationships. These come in the form of a “functional dependency.” The idea being that, if we want to ensure that a type is an output type, we would do something like:

class MultiTypeOp a b out | a b -> out where
  (\\) :: a -> b -> out

This way we can lock down the relationship between a, b, and out — guarding ourselves against dumb users.
